p: The gut motility activity of H. pubescens was investigated by Gilani et al., [ 128]. They investigated the mechanism behind this activity of H. pubescens by testing extracts on high K +-induced contractions. The high K + (> 30â€‰mM) causes contraction of smooth muscles by opening L-type Ca ++ channels, thus allowing entry of Ca ++ in the cell and producing a contractile effect. Thus, an inhibitor of K +-induced contraction is an inhibitor of the Ca ++ influx. In their study, hydro-ethanolic crude extract of H. pubescens relaxed the high K+-induced contractions just like a standard Ca++ antagonist. Thus, it was concluded that it effectively causes Ca ++ channel blocking. Therefore, these extracts may be effective for treating gut disorders such as abdominal cramps and diarrhea.
